Triggers on: 'remember this', 'save this', 'note this', 'what did we discuss about...', 'check your notes', 'clean up memories'. Also use proactively when discovering valuable findings worth preserving.

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based documentation skill with no code execution capabilities. It defines memory storage structure and usage guidelines for Claude agents. Contains no scripts, network calls, filesystem access beyond standard skill directory, environment variable access, or external command execution.

content.user_title: Save and recall knowledge across conversations
content.value_statement: Claude forgets important details between sessions. This skill provides a persistent memory system for storing discoveries, patterns, and solutions you need to access later. Your AI assistant maintains context that would otherwise be lost.
actual_capabilities: Saves discoveries, patterns, and solutions to persistent markdown files
Organizes memories into category folders with frontmatter metadata
Recalls relevant memories before working on related tasks
Searches memories by keyword, tag, or summary
Updates or consolidates memories as knowledge evolves
limitations: Memory files are plain text markdown - no structured database queries
Search is limited to keyword matching and tag filtering
No automatic deduplication of similar memories
Memory organization depends on consistent manual categorization

use_cases.title: Remember technical decisions
use_cases.description: Document why you chose a specific architecture, workarounds for library bugs, and lessons learned during complex implementations.

use_cases.title: Preserve research findings
use_cases.description: Save key sources, data patterns, and conclusions from investigations so you can build on previous work in new sessions.

use_cases.title: Track infrastructure patterns
use_cases.description: Remember deployment configurations, environment-specific quirks, and solutions to recurring operational issues.

prompt_templates.title: Save discovery
prompt_templates.prompt: Remember this for future sessions: [describe what you discovered, why it matters, and when it applies]

prompt_templates.title: Recall context
prompt_templates.prompt: What do I know about [topic] from previous conversations? Check my memories.

prompt_templates.title: Document pattern
prompt_templates.prompt: Document this pattern: [describe the issue, root cause, and solution]. Create a memory with tags for future reference.

prompt_templates.title: Organize knowledge
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my memories about [topic]. Consolidate related notes and suggest a better organization structure.

best_practices: Include specific context like file paths, version numbers, and error messages in memories
Use descriptive tags that match how you will search for information later
Update memories when the information changes or becomes outdated
anti_patterns: Saving every trivial detail instead of genuinely useful information
Using vague summaries that do not help identify relevant memories
Leaving outdated information that could mislead future sessions

faq.question: What platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Claude Code, and other Claude-powered IDE extensions that support the skills directory structure.

faq.question: How much information can I store?
faq.answer: Memory storage is limited only by your disk space. Each memory is a markdown file stored in the local skills directory.

faq.question: Can I use this with other Claude projects?
faq.answer: Yes, you can copy the skill folder to any project. Each project maintains its own independent memory database.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Memory files are gitignored by default and stored locally. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why are my memories not found in git?
faq.answer: The .gitignore file excludes all memory files. This protects sensitive project details from being committed accidentally.

faq.question: How is this different from project documentation?
faq.answer: Project docs describe what the project is. Memories describe what you learned while working on the project - decisions, gotchas, and solutions.
